section.title: About Instrumentation
section.p: The Grinder allows a script to mark the parts of the script code that should be recorded. This is called instrumentation.

Code is instrumented for a Test. When instrumented code is called, the test's statistics are updated. The standard statistics record the time taken, number of calls, and number of errors. Advanced scripts can add additional custom statistics.

Instrumentation can be nested. For example, you might instrument a method with Test 1, and the method code might call two HTTPRequests that are instrumented with Test 2 and Test 3. The code instrumented by Tests 2 and 3 is nested within the Test 1 code. The time recorded against the Test 1 will be greater than the total time recorded for Tests 2 and 3. It will also include any time spent in the function itself, for example calls to grinder.sleep().

The original (or traditional) instrumentation in The Grinder 3 works by extending internal classes of the Jython implementation. This approach served The Grinder well for many years, but has some significant limitations. The Grinder 3.3 includes an alternative instrumentation engine, which will become the default implementation in a future version of The Grinder.

section.title: Traditional Instrumentation
section.p: We've seen an example of using the traditional instrumentation in the introduction. To recap, you instrument an object by using a Test to create a proxy wrapper. The wrapper object then behaves like the original object. If we call the wrapper the call will be delegated through to the real object, but additionally the time taken to do the call and the number of calls will be recorded against the Test. Here's the example code again.
section.source:
from net.grinder.script import Test from net.grinder.script.Grinder import grinder
test1 = Test(1, "Log method")
# Wrap the info() method with our Test and call the result logWrapper. logWrapper = test1.wrap(grinder.logger.info)
class TestRunner: def __call__(self): logWrapper("Hello World")
section.p: Each time "Hello World" is written to the log file, the time taken will be recorded by The Grinder.
Most types of object can be instrumented.

tr.td: Each method call made through the wrapper is recorded. Arrays and primitive types cannot be instrumented.
Each method call made through the wrapper is recorded.
Each call of the wrapper is recorded.
Each call made to the wrapper to construct a new instance of the class is recorded. Calls of other static/class methods are not recorded.

section.p: As a convenience to the script author, each wrapper provides a __test__ field that can be used to access the test, and a __target__ field which returns the original, unwrapped object.

section.title: New Instrumentation
Motivation - why is a new instrumentation engine required?
section.p: The most serious limitation of the traditional instrumentation is that it does not work with Jython 2.5 or later. Jython 2.5 significantly changed internal APIs upon which The Grinder depends in a manner that prevents the continuation of the proxy wrapper approach. The new instrumentation takes a different approach using a Java 6 feature, and supports Jython 2.5.

In addition, the traditional instrumentation is deeply tied to Jython. It cannot be used with other scripting languages such as Clojure, nor can it be used within Java code called by the script. Both of these are possible with the new instrumentation.

section.title: Enabling the new instrumentation
section.p: The new instrumentation was first released in The Grinder 3.3. It is based on byte code modification, and requires The Grinder to be run using a Java Virtual Machine that supports transformation of already loaded classes. Practically, this means a Java 6 JVM or later. First check you are using at least The Grinder 3.3 and a Java 6 JVM.
When you start an agent process, you will normally see a line like this in the worker process log file.
section.source: 16/11/09 07:49:40 (process paston01-0) instrumentation agents: traditional Jython instrumenter
section.p: The new instrumentation is enabled by setting the grinder.dcrinstrumentation property to true. If you start an agent with this property set, the line in the log file changes.
section.source: 16/11/09 08:02:18 (process paston01-0): instrumentation agents: byte code transforming instrumenter for Jython 2.1/2.2; byte code transforming instrumenter for Java
section.p: If you see the following line, you should check you are using The Grinder 3.3, a Java 6 JVM, and you have set the grinder.dcrinstrumentation property.
section.source: 16/11/09 07:59:42 (process paston01-0): instrumentation agents: NO INSTRUMENTER COULD BE LOADED

section.warning:
The current version of Oracle JRockit has a known bug (8894099) in its implementation of java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation.retransformClasses() that can cause the same byte code transformation to be applied multiple times if instrumentation is applied more than than once for a method.
The Grinder instrumentation unit tests will fail under JRockit. However, the instrumentation engine is coded defensively and the bug should not cause any problem at runtime, other than a very minor inefficiency.

section.title: New API - record(), not wrap()
section.p: The traditional instrumenter creates separate wrapper proxy objects, and does not modify the instrumented target objects. In contrast, the new instrumentation modifies target objects directly. Once an object has been instrumented, it cannot be obtained in its original, un-instrumented form.

To reflect this change in behaviour, a new record method has been introduced into the script API. This method does not return a value, since there is no separate wrapper. Here's our example script rewritten to use record.
section.source:
from net.grinder.script import Test from net.grinder.script.Grinder import grinder
test1 = Test(1, "Log method")
# Instrument the info() method with our Test. test1.record(grinder.logger.info)
class TestRunner: def __call__(self): grinder.logger.info("Hello World")
section.p: The instrumented objects are changed in-place, so the new instrumentation provides no way to obtain the original object, and no __target__ reference. Additionally, the __test__ reference is not supported.

If you call record without enabling the new instrumentation, an exception will be thrown. To allow existing scripts to be reused with the new instrumentation, the reverse is not true. That is, wrap will use the new instrumentation engine if it is enabled. Since wrap will return its parameter, and not a separate wrapper object, the script may behave differently.
The Grinder 3.7 adds an overloaded version of record that allows the target object to be instrumented selectively.

Selective instrumentation is useful for instrumenting instances of the HTTPRequest class, which has ancilliary methods that typically need to be called without affecting test statistics. With the traditional instrumentation, this could be avoided through the __target__ reference. Here's an example of how to use selective instrumentation.
section.source:
from net.grinder.script import Test from net.grinder.plugin.http import HTTPRequest
test = Test(1, "my test")
class GetAndPostFilter(Test.InstrumentationFilter): def matches(self, method): return method.name in ["GET", "POST"]
request = HTTPRequest(url="http://grinder.sourceforge.net") test.record(request, GetAndPostFilter())
class TestRunner: def __call__(self): # Call to request.GET() is instrumented. request.GET()
# Call to request.getUrl() is not instrumented. print "Called %s" % request.url

section.title: Supported targets
section.p: A wider range of target objects can be instrumented with the new instrumentation engine, and the behaviour for some target types is different.

tr.td: Each call to a non-static method is recorded, including calls to super classes methods. Arrays cannot be instrumented.
Each call made to a constructor or a static method declared by the class is recorded. Calls of non-static methods or static methods inherited from super classes are not recorded.
Each call to an instance method is recorded.
Each call of the function or method is recorded.
Each call made to the Jython class (i.e. constructor calls) is recorded.
Each call of the function is recorded.

section.p: In addition to the above rules, JVM classes loaded in the bootstrap classloader, and classes from The Grinder's net.grinder.engine.process implementation package cannot be instrumented.

section.title: The future
section.p: The new instrumentation engine will become the default implementation in The Grinder 3.8, and the wrap method will be deprecated and eventually removed.
